bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: In the Circuit Court of the United States, Ninth Judicial Circuit, District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the matter of F. S. Walton, on habeas corpus.
div1.p: John G. Boyle makes return to the writ of Habeas Corpus served upon him by A. L. Dilley, Deputy United States Marshal for the District of Washington, upon the 7th day of September, 1901, in the above entitled matter, which writ is hereto attached, and respectfull shows:
1. That he is the regularly elected, qualified and acting city Marshal of the City of North Yakima.
2. That the City of North Yakima now is and was at all times hereinafter mentioned, duly incorporated under the laws of the State of Washington as a City of the third class.

3. That on the 4th day of April, 1898, the City Council of of said City of North Yakima, passed an ordinance No. 265, entitled an ordinance in relation to licenses, which ordinance was on the 5th day of April, 1898, duly approved by O.A. Fechter, Mayor of said City and which ordinance was thereafter duly published and in pursuance of law and recorded in the ordinance books of said City, a copy of which is hereto attached, marked exhibit "A"and made a part of this return. That on the 3 day of September, 1900, the City Council of said City of North Yakima, passed an ordinance No. 298, entitled an ordinance to amend sections 1 and 10 of said ordinance No. 265, entitled an ordinance relating to licenses aprroved April 5th, 1898, which ordinance relating to licenses approved April 5th, 1898, which ordinance was duly approved on the 4th day of September, 1900, by George S. Hough, Mayor Pro tem, and which ordinance was thereafter published and recorded in the ordinance book of said City of North Yakima, a copy of which is hereto attached, marked exhibit "B" and made a part of this return.
4. That said ordinances now are and ever since the date of their
passage, approval and publication, have been in full force and effect

5. That on the 5th day of September, 1901, the above named relator, F. S. Walton, in violation of said ordinances and without first having procured a license therefor, so to do, did unlawfully hawk certain goods, wares and merchandise, to-wit:

Quaker herbs in the City of North Yakima, by offering said quaker herbs for sale in said City and by selling the same at public out-cry in a public place therein as more fully appears from the complaint for the violation of said ordinances, a copy of which is to this return attached.

6. That thereupon a complaint, for the violation of said ordinances duly verified by Vestal Snyder, City Attorney of said City, was duly filed on the 5th day of September, 1901, with W. I. Lince who at the time was the duly appointed, or qualified and acting police justice of said City of North Yakima, a copy of which complaint with the endorsements thereon, is hereto attached, marked exhibit "C" and made a part of this return.

7. That thereupon, on the said 5th day of September, 1901, the said police justice duly issued a warrant for the apprehension and arrest of said relator, which warrant was duly placed in thehands of this respondent and thereupon on the said 5th day of September, 1901, pursuant to the commands therein contained, this respondent duly arrested and took into custody said relator and took him before said police justice and thereupon, upon the application of said relator, a change of venue was granted from said police justice to J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace of North Yakima Precinct, in Yakima County, State of Washington, being the nearest Justice of the Peace.

8. That afterwards, on the 6th day of September, 1901, said cause came on regularly for trial before said J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, and after the hearing thereof said relator being present in person and by his counsel, a judgment was rendered in said Court and cause, whereby it was considered that said relator pay a fine of Five Dollars, together with the costs of said action, a copy of which judgment is hereto attached, marked exhibit "D"
and made a part of this return.

9. that said relator having failed and refused to pay said fine and costs, a commitment was issued by said J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, and placed in the hands of this respondent and thereupon by virtue of the commands therein contained, did take said relator into custody on the 6th day of September, 1901, and placed him in the City jail of the City of North Yakima, a copy of which commitment is hereto attached, marked exhibit "E" and made a part of this return.

10. That said relator so remained in jail until the 7th day of September, 1901, at the hour of ten o'clock A.M., this respondent discharged said relator from custody and never since said time has the said John G. Boyle had the custody or control of said relator nor has he imprisoned him nor restrained him of his liberty nor has he had the said relator in his possession, custody or power since said date and he now has no power, custody or control over him.

11. Said respondent further shows that said writ of habeas corpus was served upon him on the 7th day of September, 1901, at the hour of four o'clock P.M. That respondent had no notice, power prior to said date and did not at said date, nor at any other time prior to the time the same was served upon him, have any notice or knowledge that said writ or any writ of habeas corpus has been issued.

12. That this respondent does not hold said relator by virtue of said commitment or by process of any Court whatever but pursuant to the commands in said writ of habeas corpus named, the respondent with the full consent and at the express request of said relator and with the full knowledge on the part of the said relator, of all the facts herein stated, and in order to obey said writ of habeas corpus in so far as it was in the power of this respondent so to do, has brought said relator into this Court by virtue of said writ of habeas corpus and not otherwise and has brought said relator into Court at his express request and with his full consent and with his full knowledge, that he was not detained under commitment aforesaid nor under process of any other Court of this and this respondent now

avers that since he released and discharged said relator from custody on the said 7th day of September, 1901, that he has restr not restrained him of his liberty and that he has not had him under his power, possession or control.

13-- Respondent further avers that said relator is engaged in the sale of what are generally known as patent medicines; that relator represents himself as a Quaker Doctor, and that he hawks and vends said medicines by travelling from town to town and offering the same at public outcry upon the streets and public places of various towns visited by him; that said relator carries with him a travelling troup of players, and gives open air concerts for the purpose of attracting corwds of people, in order to be able to more readily sell his wares; that he is engaged in the sale of what is known as "Quaker Herbs", "Pile Remedies" and shaving soap; that the method of conducting the business of said relator attracts large crowds of people on the streets, thoroughfares and public places where said business is carried on; that by reason thereof the said City of North Yakima is put to large additional expense in policing said city and preserving the public peace and good order therein.

14-- Said relator, as this respondent is informed and believes and therefore alleges, sells large quantities of the medicines and nostrums aforesaid at an enormous profit, and this respondent averts that said relator can well afford from the profits made and the quantitites of medicine sold to pay the license in said ordinance mentioned.

15-- That said relator ships said medicines and nostrums into the State of Washington in original packages, and thereafter and when the same are offered for sale, he breaks said packages and offers the same for sale at retail in single packages and not in the packages so shipped in.
16-- Respondent further making return to said writ, denies that said relator is unlawfully imprisoned, detained and fined or restrained of his liberty by respondent at North

Yakima or elsewhere; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether said relator is a resident and citizen of the City of Portland in the State of Oregon; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether the trade mark "Quaker Medicine" has been filed by the relator and as to whether he ahs taken out a trade mark under the laws of the United States; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to what said medicine is composed of, and as to whether it is not composed of the products of the soil or vegetables of Yakima County; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether the component parts of said medicine and quaker herbs and nostrums are grown in various States of the United States other than the State of Washington; denies that said relator was detained by respondent under said committment at the time of the granting of said writ; denies that the sum of Four Hundred Dollars ($400.00) is a prohibitive and unreasonable license, and that Twenty- five Dollars ($25.00) per day is a prohibitive and unreasonable license; denies that the net profits from the sale of said medicine would not equal said license; and denies that the effect of said license is to prohibit petitioner from doing business in the City of North Yakima; and denies that it infringes his right under the Constitution of the United States to engage in business in North Yakima upon equal terms with the persons selling the products of Yakima County, and that it interferes with the right of commerce as guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States between the citizens of different states; denies that said ordinance is in violation of the Constitution and laws of the

United States; denies that said ordinance discriminates against the residents and products of all other portions of the United States in favor of the products of Yakima County; denies that said ordinance is in violation of the right of commerce; denies that it is a violation of the Constitution of the United States which gives to the citizens of each State of the Union like privileges, rights and immunities in every other State of said Union had by the citizens of said State.

14. That respondent respectfully protests against the jursidiction of this Court and respectfully avers that the matters and things aforesaid do not show a violation of the constitution of the laws of the United States.
WHEREFORE respendent prays that said writ of habeas corpus be quashed and that said petition be dismissed and that he recover his costs.
div1.ab: State of Washington, County of King,
div1.p: John G. Boyle being duly sworn deposes and says that he is the respondent above named; that he has read and knows the contents of the foregoing return and the same is true as he verily believes.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 9th day of September, 1901.
div1.ab:
Notary Public for Washington, residing at North Yakima, Wn..
Deputy Clerk U.S. District Court, District of Washington.
